quotes.topic_title: Mission-driven impact at the New York Times
quotes.text: One thing that's really interesting is that our impact and our business goals are in service of our mission, which is to seek the truth and help people understand the world, not the other way around.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: A clear mission-first mental model for aligning product/business metrics as downstream of purpose rather than the driver.

quotes.topic_title: Mission-driven impact at the New York Times
quotes.text: That business exists to strengthen an informed democracy at a time when people are struggling to understand basic facts and struggling to understand each other.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: Connects commercial strategy to a concrete societal outcome, useful for practitioners framing stakeholder narratives around impact.

quotes.topic_title: Mission-driven impact at the New York Times
quotes.text: That means that impact for us is growing subscribers, but it's also when a deeply reported story triggers an important policy change or a new law.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: Defines impact as both metric growth and real-world change, offering a dual-impact lens teams can adopt.

quotes.topic_title: Mission-driven impact at the New York Times
quotes.text: When you're a product manager, you're involved again in driving specific metrics like engagement or subscribers, but you're also trying to help stories find their real audience in ways that trigger just this whole different side of mission and purpose driven impact.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: Practical reframing of PM work: optimize metrics while designing distribution to reach the right audience for mission outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Mission-driven impact at the New York Times
quotes.text: I didn't feel that when I was at a place like Facebook.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: A contrarian contrast that challenges the assumption that metric-driven product work always feels mission-aligned across companies.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: As you'll hear in our conversation, Alex has been at the center of the storm so many times, including at Facebook right after the 2016 election.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights high-stakes product leadership experience in crisis moments, setting up lessons about operating under intense scrutiny.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Then, at the New York Times right as COVID hit.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Points to another major external shock that likely shaped how product teams prioritize and execute during disruption.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Creating a product, especially one that your users can't live without is damn hard, but it's made easier by working closely with your colleagues to capture ideas, get feedback, and being able to iterate quickly.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: tight collaboration and fast iteration are presented as key levers to building indispensable products.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With Miro, you can build out your product strategy by brainstorming with sticky notes, comments, slide reactions, voting tools, even a timer to keep your team on track.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable toolkit for running structured strategy sessions with a team (including facilitation mechanics like voting and timeboxing).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You can also bring your whole distributed team together around wire frames where anyone can draw their own ideas with pen tool or put their own images or mockups right into the Miro board.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical method for collaborative design in distributed teams—co-creating directly on shared wireframes rather than passing files around.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With one of Miro's ready made templates, you can go from discovery and research, to product roadmaps, to customer journey flows, to final mocks.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: An end-to-end workflow model that connects research to execution artifacts, reducing handoff gaps across the product lifecycle.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Two, they treat AG1 like a software product. Apparently, they're on their 52nd iteration and they're constantly evolving it based on the latest science, research studies, and internal testing that they do.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A cross-domain product mindset—iterating a physical product with software-style continuous improvement, backed by a specific iteration count.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: One, with a small scoop that dissolves in water, you are absorbing 75 vitamins, minerals, probiotics, and adaptogens.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A specific, quantifiable claim that can be used as an example of concise value communication (one action delivering many inputs).

quotes.topic_title: Career path: NYT, Facebook, Atlantic, return
quotes.text: I've definitely spent most of my career right at the intersection of journalism and tech.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: A clear positioning strategy: building a career by intentionally operating at the intersection of two domains.

quotes.topic_title: Career path: NYT, Facebook, Atlantic, return
quotes.text: I was just rolling with it and following what felt like a really interesting set of problems to solve.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: A practical career heuristic: choose roles based on the quality of problems rather than titles or linear progression.

quotes.topic_title: Career path: NYT, Facebook, Atlantic, return
quotes.text: The first was really trying to work with the company to shift from being a print first product into a mobile first product.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: A concrete transformation playbook: reorient the organization around a new primary platform (mobile-first) rather than bolting on features.

quotes.topic_title: Career path: NYT, Facebook, Atlantic, return
quotes.text: We just really started investing in small mobile use cases, first on the margins and then more and more aggressively until we were just leading with mobile in everything that we did.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: An actionable sequencing model for change: start with edge experiments, then scale investment until the new channel becomes the default.

quotes.topic_title: Career path: NYT, Facebook, Atlantic, return
quotes.text: there was just a lot of skepticism, including from people at The New York Times, about whether or not people would pay for quality journalism.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: A counterintuitive lesson for monetization: even insiders may underestimate willingness-to-pay for high-quality value.

quotes.topic_title: Wartime product management after 2016 election
quotes.text: I think about wartime product management, right?
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: A memorable framing for operating in high-stakes, high-urgency environments where normal product cycles and assumptions break down.

quotes.topic_title: Wartime product management after 2016 election
quotes.text: What I appreciated about that time inside of Facebook was that there was just this incredible humility that was needed to really understand and first diagnose what was actually happening on the platform,
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: Highlights a practical operating principle: start with humility and diagnosis before jumping to solutions in crisis situations.

quotes.topic_title: Wartime product management after 2016 election
quotes.text: the approach to content on Facebook historically it was very binary. You basically had content from friends and family and then you had public contents.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: Calls out a simplifying assumption (“binary” content model) that can fail under real-world pressure and motivates more nuanced classification systems.

quotes.topic_title: Wartime product management after 2016 election
quotes.text: What we really tried to do very quickly was try to unpack the categories of public content to say that there actually is something that is factually accurate information, and that requires a certain craft from the journalistic trade.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: Describes an actionable methodology: break down broad categories and explicitly model “trusted” vs. misleading information, including the role of domain expertise.

quotes.topic_title: Wartime product management after 2016 election
quotes.text: It was really fascinating and really hard just because the platform hadn't been built to think about classification of coverage in that way.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: A concrete lesson about platform constraints: product architecture and prior assumptions can make critical interventions (like classification) unusually difficult.

quotes.topic_title: Thriving in chaos and high-stakes work
quotes.text: I just actually think that that's where product people thrive. The idea of being able to take all of these crazy inputs, trying to create a very structured model to figure out, "Okay, what is true? Where do we have conviction? Where do we have questions? What are the most important problems to solve? How do you prioritize? How do you get a team rallied around a shared context in one single goal? These are actually the conditions where product manager, I think, thrive.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: A practical mental model for operating in chaos: turn messy inputs into truth/conviction/questions, then prioritize and align the team on one goal.

quotes.topic_title: Thriving in chaos and high-stakes work
quotes.text: But it does take a certain amount of just grit and resilience, and the ability to really focus on the most important problems in a given moment. Also, the ability to let other things slide when you have to.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: Actionable leadership advice for high-stakes environments: focus ruthlessly and explicitly deprioritize non-essentials.

quotes.topic_title: Thriving in chaos and high-stakes work
quotes.text: But again, I feel like these are core product skills that we look for in terms of leadership and grit, and the ability to drive through really, really tough problems that there's no playbook for, nobody has ever really done before.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: Highlights a key hiring/leadership criterion for PMs: succeeding when there’s no established playbook.

quotes.topic_title: Thriving in chaos and high-stakes work
quotes.text: There's a metaphor I like to use when I give PM's advice on where to work within a company, which is there's like the Eye of Sauron, which is the number one most important thing to the CEO at that time.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable framework for choosing what to work on: identify the CEO’s top focus area (“Eye of Sauron”).

quotes.topic_title: Thriving in chaos and high-stakes work
quotes.text: My advice is often don't avoid that thing, usually, but work maybe to the side of that because you don't want to work on something that doesn't matter, that's like over in the shire land. You want to be something that matters but not maybe the most important thing.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Counterintuitive career/product strategy: stay adjacent to the highest-priority initiative to balance impact with survivable pressure.

quotes.topic_title: Returning to NYT and rejoining as leader
quotes.text: It almost felt as like, I'm going on an externship and I really hope that one day I'll be able to come back and just do my job better.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: A reframing of leaving a company as a deliberate learning tour with the goal of returning stronger.

quotes.topic_title: Returning to NYT and rejoining as leader
quotes.text: Because I do think there's real value in being able to do product in a bunch of different contexts. You're just so much better at pattern recognition, learning how to solve a diversity of problems, learning to work through things.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: Highlights cross-context experience as a practical way to build pattern recognition and problem-solving range in product work.

quotes.topic_title: Returning to NYT and rejoining as leader
quotes.text: My interview process, I joked with my boss at the time. But it did actually feel more like therapy.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: A counterintuitive take that the best interviews can be reflective and developmental rather than transactional Q&A.

quotes.topic_title: Returning to NYT and rejoining as leader
quotes.text: When you've worked with people for a decade before and you go in, the conversation isn't the normal list of interview questions. It's like, "Okay, here's what type of leader you were a couple of years ago. Here are the conditions on the ground now, how do you feel about X? How do you feel about Y? Are you still passionate about solving this? What else have you learned that's going to make you better?"
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: Provides a concrete template for a growth-oriented interview focused on past leadership, current context, motivation, and learning.

quotes.topic_title: Returning to NYT and rejoining as leader
quotes.text: It was one of the best interview processes because you're talking to a bunch of people who knew what you were like when you were leading as a person at a different point in your career and they're pushing you to be better.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: Emphasizes the value of interviews anchored in long-term relationships that can challenge you based on real prior performance.

quotes.topic_title: Defining NYT’s product and the subscription bundle
quotes.text: At the most basic level, I would say that our product is our journalism, which we then marry with a really compelling and useful user experience, in a way that helps people really act on our journalism so that they can understand and engage with the world around them.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: A clear product definition framework: core value (journalism) + UX that enables users to take action and engage.

quotes.topic_title: Defining NYT’s product and the subscription bundle
quotes.text: But about 25 years ago, when we started shifting over to digital, the web, and mobile, the world just fully opened up in a way.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: Captures the strategic inflection point of digital: from bounded products to an unbounded ecosystem that changes distribution and product scope.

quotes.topic_title: Defining NYT’s product and the subscription bundle
quotes.text: When we then pivoted though to a subscription model, it was a really interesting moment where we actually had to take more of a destination first approach.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: Actionable go-to-market/product strategy: subscriptions push you to build owned destinations rather than relying on distributed platforms.

quotes.topic_title: Defining NYT’s product and the subscription bundle
quotes.text: Because in order to build a really thriving subscription business, you really need a direct relationship with your customer as opposed to just relying on platforms to really distribute your coverage.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: A practical principle for subscription businesses: prioritize direct customer relationships over platform-dependent distribution.

quotes.topic_title: Defining NYT’s product and the subscription bundle
quotes.text: The next thing for us to do is to really figure out how to put those together into a bundle that really becomes the essential subscription for any curious English speaking person around the world, who really wants to know what's happening and wants to be able to, again, act and engage and make great decisions based on the products that we build.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: A memorable bundling vision that frames product expansion as creating an “essential subscription” for a defined audience.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy: 15M subscribers and portfolio growth
quotes.text: What we found was that there are about 135 million people around the world we believe are willing to pay for the type of high quality journalism based products that the New York Times produces, in the categories of news, gameplay, cooking and recipes, sports, which is why we acquired the athletic shopping recommendations and audio.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: A concrete TAM estimate plus the specific product categories (and acquisitions) they’re using to expand the subscription value proposition.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy: 15M subscribers and portfolio growth
quotes.text: The first is we absolutely need to have the best news destination in the world.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: Clarifies that portfolio expansion only works if the core product remains world-class and anchors the brand.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy: 15M subscribers and portfolio growth
quotes.text: When you think about the New York Times, we actually have the solar system metaphor where for us news is the sun in the sense that it's why we exist.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for structuring a portfolio: a core “sun” product that powers adjacent “planets.”

quotes.topic_title: Strategy: 15M subscribers and portfolio growth
quotes.text: But then that sun helps you give birth to other satellite planets or products that have a lot of the same DNA.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: Explains how to extend into new products without diluting the brand—reuse the same underlying “DNA.”

quotes.topic_title: Strategy: 15M subscribers and portfolio growth
quotes.text: We want to get to 15 million subscribers by 2027. We're just over 9 million today, and I really think we can do it.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: A specific, time-bound growth target that frames the scale of ambition and the gap the strategy must close.

quotes.topic_title: Org structure: functions, missions, and embedded editors
quotes.text: For us, when we think about our org structure, the way to set that up so that our people can really do their best work is that we have two axis. We have functions and then we have missions.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: Introduces a clear, reusable org-design framework: a dual-axis model separating functional excellence from mission execution.

quotes.topic_title: Org structure: functions, missions, and embedded editors
quotes.text: The functions themselves, it's normal of what you would find in terms of functional responsibilities. We focus on standards of craft and excellence, career growth, career frameworks, equitable promotion processes, community of practices, skill development, all of that.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: Clarifies what to centralize in functions to scale quality and people systems while missions focus on outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Org structure: functions, missions, and embedded editors
quotes.text: But missions is where a lot of the work happens. These are cross-functional teams, very similar to what we had at a place like Facebook.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: Emphasizes that execution and delivery live in cross-functional missions, not functional silos—useful for structuring ownership and velocity.

quotes.topic_title: Org structure: functions, missions, and embedded editors
quotes.text: But the big difference is we also have editors, if it's a product space that directly shapes our journalism.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: A counterintuitive team composition move—embedding domain authorities (editors) directly into product teams when the product shapes the core craft.

quotes.topic_title: Org structure: functions, missions, and embedded editors
quotes.text: But we have three different types of missions. We have consumer missions, we have monetization missions, and we have platform missions. Editors are embedded within consumer missions.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: Provides a concrete mission taxonomy practitioners can copy, plus a rule for where to embed editorial/domain roles.

quotes.topic_title: Building immersive storytelling and scalable formats
quotes.text: I do think there's something really special about some of the ways that we marry the journalism and the presentation. I want to start just by giving credit where credit's due, which is I think some of the most interesting and inventive and compelling formats, they actually do start off as one-off experiments that are spun up in the newsroom by embedded teams that we have within graphics, visual journalism, interactive news teams.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: A repeatable model: let embedded, cross-functional teams run one-off experiments that later seed scalable formats.

quotes.topic_title: Building immersive storytelling and scalable formats
quotes.text: The speed of news is so fast that you don't have time to mess with roadmaps. We really have teams who are freed up from some of the normal processes around that, so they can really just focus on storytelling for really big stories and pieces.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: Counterintuitive operating principle: for high-velocity work, remove standard roadmap/process overhead to maximize impact.

quotes.topic_title: Building immersive storytelling and scalable formats
quotes.text: First, they have to be able to think in the moment with editors, where you might not always have all the right data at your fingertips and you just have to make a call, like, "What is the best experience to tell this story in a really truthful, accurate, accessible way?" Then, the other mode is when they're not shipping at the speed of news, they're trying to build end to end systems so that we're building the tooling to actually create the stories at the same time as the consumer experience, which is a totally different mode of system level thinking.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: A practical “two-mode” product framework: rapid editorial decision-making now, plus system/tooling investment for repeatability later.

quotes.topic_title: Building immersive storytelling and scalable formats
quotes.text: If you even look at live, we've broken out of the tyranny of the article in many ways, where you have live reporter updates that are the size of length of tweets. People filing from the ground in Ukraine, trying to give you a sense of what's happening in a very immediate and real way.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: A concrete example of format innovation: shifting from long articles to tweet-length live updates to match real-time reporting needs.

quotes.topic_title: Building immersive storytelling and scalable formats
quotes.text: The majority are on our platforms hands down. Yeah. Yeah.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: A clear signal that scalable platforms—not bespoke one-offs—power most “fancy” immersive stories over time.

quotes.topic_title: Wordle acquisition and integration challenges
quotes.text: The whole thing took place in a matter of weeks, which is way faster than any other acquisition I've been a part of.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: A concrete data point showing how quickly a strategic acquisition can move when fit and conviction are high.

quotes.topic_title: Wordle acquisition and integration challenges
quotes.text: I do think there's also a real lesson for a lot of companies, not only about when you acquire what's the opportunity, but also are you ready to actually integrate an acquisition?
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: A practitioner-focused reminder to evaluate integration readiness—not just deal rationale—before acquiring.

quotes.topic_title: Wordle acquisition and integration challenges
quotes.text: When we acquired Wordle, it was a simple web game with no backend.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: Highlights a common integration challenge: beloved products may lack infrastructure needed for scale, portability, and reliability.

quotes.topic_title: Wordle acquisition and integration challenges
quotes.text: What we decided to do was undertake a project to connect Wordle to a New York Times account, which was free, because Wordle is a free game, just so that it knows who you are and so that your stats and streaks can be protected.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: Actionable integration pattern: add identity/account linkage to preserve user value (stats/streaks) without changing the core loop.

quotes.topic_title: Wordle acquisition and integration challenges
quotes.text: This is where coming out being really transparent about the facts and in some cases just exposing more about the product development process really helps demystify some of the rumors that people might otherwise think.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: Crisis/incident playbook: transparency about technical realities can reduce speculation during sensitive product moments.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: SOC 2 is a way to prove your company's taking proper security measures to protect customer data and builds trust with customers and partners, especially those with serious security requirements.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Frames SOC 2 as a trust-building mechanism and a concrete way to communicate security posture to demanding buyers.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Also, if you want to sell to the enterprise, proving security is essential.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable reminder that enterprise go-to-market success often depends on demonstrable security readiness, not just product value.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: SOC 2 can either open the door for bigger and better deals or it can put your business on hold.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Memorable articulation of SOC 2 as a gating factor that can accelerate or stall revenue growth.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you don't have a SOC 2, there's a good chance you won't even get a seat at the table.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a counterintuitive reality: without baseline compliance, you may be excluded before product evaluation even begins.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Enter Vanta, over 3000 fast growing companies use Vanta to automate up to 90% of the work involved with SOC 2.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a concrete adoption data point and a measurable claim (up to 90% automation) that practitioners can benchmark against.

quotes.topic_title: COVID response: rebuilding priorities and public service
quotes.text: This is a product leader, it's a real wartime moment where you just need to blow up roadmaps, share context with everyone and say, "Okay, everyone, we have a totally different mandate than what we did a couple weeks ago."
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: A crisis-mode product leadership framework: reset priorities fast, over-communicate context, and explicitly redefine the mandate.

quotes.topic_title: COVID response: rebuilding priorities and public service
quotes.text: We're going to build a comprehensive public data set of COVID cases. Nobody else is doing it.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: A concrete example of identifying an unmet public need and committing to fill the gap as a product strategy.

quotes.topic_title: COVID response: rebuilding priorities and public service
quotes.text: We really just started scraping and pulling this together, and what was a single spreadsheet at the time.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: Shows an MVP methodology: start with the simplest artifact (a spreadsheet) and iterate into a scalable dataset/tooling.

quotes.topic_title: COVID response: rebuilding priorities and public service
quotes.text: We made our most important COVID coverage free to everybody. It was really important that if it was something related to public safety, we didn't put it behind a paywall.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: A mission-driven decision rule practitioners can apply: remove monetization friction when information is critical to safety.

quotes.topic_title: COVID response: rebuilding priorities and public service
quotes.text: But building purposeful products that made a really difficult moment feel not only possible but promising, was one of the most unifying moments, I would say, for our teams.
quotes.speaker: Alex Hardiman
quotes.context: Highlights a counterintuitive team dynamic: high-stress periods can unify teams when the work is clearly mission-aligned.
